chapter.title: Getting started with JBoss AS 7
chapter.para: To run the examples with the provided build scripts, you'll need the following:

listitem.para: the JBoss AS 7 distribution zip, which contains the examples
Maven 3, to build and deploy the examples

chapter.para: Follow the offical Maven installation guide if you don't already have Maven 3 installed. You can check which version of Maven you have installed (if any) by running mvn --version. If you see a version string printed, you are ready to go.
Now, download JBoss AS from the JBoss AS 7 page.

note.para: JBoss AS 7 offers the ability to manage multiple AS instances from a single control point. A collection of such servers are referred to as members of a "domain", with a single Domain Controller process acting as the management control point. Domains can span multiple physical (or virtual) machines, with all AS instances on a given host under the control of a Host Controller process. The Host Controllers interact with the Domain Controller to control the lifecycle of the AS instances running on that host and to assist the Domain Controller in managing them.
JBoss AS 7 also offers a standalone mode, which is perfect for a single server. We use this throughout the quickstart examples.

section.title: Installing and starting JBoss AS on Windows
section.para: First, we need to choose a location for JBoss AS to live. By default, JBoss AS 7 will be extracted into jboss-7.x.x.x (where 7.x.x.x matches the version you downloaded). Unzip JBoss AS using your tool of choice.
We now need to set the JBOSS_HOME environment variable:

orderedlist.listitem: Right click on My Computer and select Properties
Click to the Advanced tab and click on the button at the bottom that says Environment Variables
Create a System property named JBOSS_HOME and point it to the directory you extracted JBoss AS to
